lines.content: 1. Ensure you have Java 11 or above installed in your Computer.
3. Run `java -jar Duke.jar` to run the app.
4. After the app is lauching, you will see the greeting from Duke:
What can I do for you?
5. Type the command and enjoy the app!
+ Duke supports date function, ensure the date is the format of `yyyy-MM-dd`, e.g. `2020-10-01`; otherwise the date will be treated as string only.
+ todo`[T]`: tasks without any date/time attached to it
+ deadline `[D]`: tasks that need to be done before a specific date/time
+ event `[E]`: tasks that start at a specific time and ends at a specific time
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 8 tasks in the list.
Note: only date-time in `yyyy-MM-dd` format will be parsed as datetime; otherwise, it will be treated as a string only.
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 9 tasks in the list.
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 10 tasks in the list.
## Mark the Task as Done: `done INDEX_OF_TASK`
+ `INDEX_OF_TASK` corresponds to the output of `list` command, e.g. it starts from 1.
Nice! I've marked this task as done:
Now you have 9 tasks in the list.
Note: all arguments provided with `list` will be ignored.
Here are the tasks in your list:
Note: the command only accepts 1 keyword; extra keywords will be ignored.
Here are the matching tasks in your list:
## Find Task based on Date: `date yyyy-mm-dd`
Note: `2020-10-6` is invalid, and it should be written as `2020-10-06`
The storage file containing all tasks in task list will be updated each time the user gives the input.
The user can specify **the storage path (relative to the current working-path)**  in the command-line argument:
If the file does not exist before, a new storage file will be created in the path; otherwise, the file's task information will be loaded into the program.
Note: If you doesn't find the directory created in the location, please changing your current directory to be the same as the jar file's.
Bye. Hope to see you again soon!
+ Mark the Task as Done: `done INDEX_OF_TASK`
+ Find Task based on Date: `date yyyy-mm-dd`
* The storage file path can be specified through command-line argument.
* The main function of Duke Application.
* @param args the path of the storage file in string
Duke app = new Duke(args[0]);  // e.g. java -jar duke.jar data/duke.txt
* Object to parse out the command according to userInput.
* @param tasks the task list of Duke
* Parses out the command based on userInput.
* @throws UnknownCommandException if the command is undefined
* @throws EmptyContentForCommandException if the description of the command is empty
public Command parseCommand(String userInput) throws UnknownCommandException, EmptyContentForCommandException {
String commandWord = userInput.split(" ")[0].toLowerCase();  // All command words are 1st word.
// dummy initialization below, because Java requires return value to be initialized in this case.
newTask = new Todo(userInput.substring(5));  // e.g. todo do homework
commandArguments = userInput.substring(9).split("/by");   // e.g. deadline do assignment /by tmr
commandArguments = userInput.substring(6).split("/at");   // e.g. event do assignment /at tmr
